title: Fibromyalgia Burns and Stabs

content: The pins-and-needles sensation that turned out to be my first fibromyalgia symptom started when I was 16. My skin tingled and turned numb on and off for years.
Once in a while I felt brief stabs. It was like someone shoved a knife between my ribs. I’d stare at the spot and wonder why I wasn’t bleeding.
Fast forward 20 years. Here’s a text I recently sent to one of my best friends:

"I woke up at 2AM and haven't been able to get back to sleep. Every inch of my skin either itches, burns, or feels like there are pieces of hair or bugs on it. Could be a fibromyalgia thing, could be a panic attack... OMG let me sleep... And I'm so hot I took everything off and turned the overhead fan on high. Something is stabbing and scratching my leg, and it won’t stop!"

Not until I started leading the WebMD Fibromyalgia Community on Facebook did I come to understand that these skin anomalies I experience are common. A frequent comment in the community is, “I experience that, too!” It turns out that this is yet another thing that isn’t just “in my head.”

content: The experts can’t seem to agree about what causes fibromyalgia. One probable cause is a disorder called central sensitization.

Many chronic conditions can be traced to the central nervous system, specifically the brain and spinal cord. Our bodies are covered in sensor cells that give us information about what we feel, taste, smell, etc. The brain makes choices based on that information. For example, if your brain sensor cells tell your brain that you’re thirsty, your brain may decide to get a drink of water.

Central sensitization, if I understand it correctly, increases the intensity of the sensor cells. Even though there’s no emergency, the sensor cells go on high alert. Eventually the intensity of everything else increases, too.

What’s a little pain for a healthy person is a lot of pain for someone living with fibromyalgia. A slight bump against a coffee table feels like getting hit by a baseball bat. A bit of dust feels like a spide r . A slight sensation of heat feels like a fire. A tiny pinch feels like a stab.

content: I’m not sure that explains everything. My body seems confused.

For example, I can’t tell the difference between wet and cold anymore. I also feel raindrops on my arm when there’s no water. Then there’s the spot on my hip where, if you touch it, I feel the pressure not there but down on my calf! I once itched so bad for half a week that I scratched my skin until it bled.
My body seems to be confused in other ways. I sometimes get chills for a whole day when there’s no sign of a fever. I’ll feel hot when other people are cold and cold when other people are hot.

Ultimately, I don’t really care about what caused the fibromyalgia. I’m here, sitting with it, and can’t go back in time. All I can do is ride the wave of symptoms, report them to the Fibromyalgia Community, and breathe a big sigh of relief when someone says, “I experience that, too!”
